--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> Let me try to address these questions.  First, is this an
> ANJI-specific question?  Which software are you using?  I just want to
> make sure since I think there is an error in the calculations you are
> citing.  More below...
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Matt Simmerson" <m.simmerson@b...>
> wrote:
> > Hi
> > 
> > Whilst calculating the number of offspring for a valid (i.e. non
> > extinct and size > 0) specie, the count returns 0.  This is
> > particularly prevalent in large species where the adjusted fitness
> > becomes quite small comapared with the rest of the other, and
> usually
> > much less populous, species. 
> > 
> > This becomes even more marked if I boost young species fitness.
> > 
> > As far as I understand, the offspring is calculated as follows.
> > 
> > (av adjusted specie fitness) / (total of all species av adjusted
> > fitnesses) * Population size.
> > 
> 
> This formula looks wrong.  It turns out there are a number of ways to
> express the number of offspring (all being mathematically equivalent
> formulations), but the specifics are crucial.  And this looks like it
> has some specifics wrong.  The formula should be:
> 
> Offspring = (AverageSpeciesFitness / Total_of_AverageSpeciesFitnesss)
> * PopulationSize 
> 
> Note that "adjusted" never comes into it.  The presence of the word
> "adjusted" in your formulation implies to me that you may be
> double-adjusting.  The adjustments come in when you are modifying
> fitnesses on a per-organism basis and assigning offspring on a
> per-organism basis.  In other words, each organism has its fitness
> divided by the total number of individuals in its species.  But if you
> then SUM all those adjusted fitness together, what do you get?  You
> get AverageSpeciesFitness, i.e. the simple average *unadjusted*
> fitness of all the organisms in the species.   
> 
> The point is this:  either you adjust the fitnesses of individuals and
> then sum those adjusted fitnesses (as I do in my version of NEAT), or
> you just take the average fitness of the species.  You do *not* do
> both.
> 
> Note also that the denominator is the sum of all the average species
> fitnesses.  No adjustment in that part either.
> 
> The problem boils down to the fact that there are two ways to express
> offspring assigned in fitness sharing as it's done in NEAT: on a
> per-species or per-individual basis.  Equations in my papers are
> usually expressed per-offspring.  It's easier to understand
> intuitively on a per-offspring basis because in those equations you
> can see how the individual's fitness is being reduced according to its
> species size.  In other words the fitness of any individual matters
> less towards how many offspring the species gets the more individuals
> are in that species.  Averaging without adjusting, however, is just a
> different way to formulate the same concept in which you don't diretly
> see the reduction according to species size.
> 
> > For example, imagine we have 3 species. Specie_1 has 3 members av
> raw
> > fitness 0.85, Specie_2 has 2 members av raw fitness 0.82 and
> Specie_3
> > has 145 members with av raw fitness 0f 0.9.
> > 
> > Specie_1(adj) = 0.85/3 = 0.28333
> > Specie_2(adj) = 0.82/2 = 0.41
> > Specie_3(adj) = 0.9/145 = 0.006
> > 
> > Specie_1 then generates 61 offspring
> > Specie_2 then generates 87 offspring
> > Specie_3 then generates 2 offspring
> > 
> 
> Again, this doesn't make sense.  If 0.9 is the average fitness of
> species 3 then it should be getting over 1/3rd of the offspring.  if a
> system is showing this behavior there may be a bug in the speciation
> code.
> 
> ken
